metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Investigate and apply theoretically and practically a field model to magnetic phenomena, including shapes and directions of fields produced by bar magnets, and by current-carrying wires, loops and solenoids

bar_magnets.title: Magnetic Fields Around Bar Magnets
bar_magnets.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of bar magnet field patterns.

sentences.text: All magnets have two ends called poles: a {{d1}} pole and a {{d2}} pole. The region around a magnet where magnetic effects can be experienced is called the {{d3}}.

d3.tooltip: The field type associated with magnets

sentences.text: Magnetic field lines around a bar magnet run from the {{d4}} pole to the {{d5}} pole outside the magnet. Field lines are closer together where the field is {{d6}}.

d4.tooltip: Field lines exit from which pole?

sentences.text: When two like poles are brought together, the magnets {{d7}}. When opposite poles face each other, the magnets {{d8}}. Magnets always exist as {{d9}}, never as isolated poles.

current_wires.title: Magnetic Fields Around Current-Carrying Wires
current_wires.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of magnetic fields produced by electric currents.

sentences.text: A straight current-carrying wire produces a magnetic field with a {{d1}} shape around the wire. The direction of this field can be found using the {{d2}} rule.

d1.tooltip: What shape do the field lines form around the wire?

sentences.text: In the right-hand grip rule, the {{d3}} points in the direction of {{d4}}, and the curled fingers show the direction of the {{d5}}.

d3.tooltip: Which part points along the wire?

d4.tooltip: Current flows from positive to negative

d5.tooltip: What do the curled fingers represent?

sentences.text: When a magnetic field goes into the page, it is represented by a {{d6}}. When it comes out of the page, it is represented by a {{d7}}.

d6.tooltip: Like seeing the tail feathers of an arrow

d7.tooltip: Like seeing the point of an arrow

loops_solenoids.title: Magnetic Fields in Loops and Solenoids
loops_solenoids.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of electromagnets.

sentences.text: A current-carrying loop concentrates the magnetic field in the {{d1}} of the loop. The direction of the field through the loop is found using the {{d2}} rule.

d2.tooltip: Different rule for coils than straight wires

sentences.text: A solenoid is a coil of wire that acts like a {{d3}} when current flows through it. The magnetic field inside a solenoid is {{d4}} and {{d5}}.

d3.tooltip: What does the field pattern resemble?

d5.tooltip: Are the field lines parallel inside?

sentences.text: In the right-hand coil rule, the curled fingers point in the direction of {{d6}}, and the thumb points in the direction of the {{d7}} inside the solenoid.

d6.tooltip: What do the curled fingers follow?

bar_magnets.title: Applying Bar Magnet Field Concepts
bar_magnets.instructions: Apply your understanding of bar magnet fields to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A compass needle aligns with local magnetic field lines. On Earth, a compass points toward geographic {{d1}} because Earth's magnetic {{d2}} pole is located there.

d1.tooltip: Which direction does a compass point?

sentences.text: When two bar magnets have opposite poles facing each other, the field between them is approximately {{d3}} with field lines running {{d4}}. When like poles face each other, the field lines {{d5}} between the magnets.

d3.tooltip: Are the field lines parallel between opposite poles?

d4.tooltip: How do lines appear between opposite poles?

d5.tooltip: Repulsion causes field lines to spread apart

sentences.text: Breaking a bar magnet in half creates {{d6}} smaller magnets, each with its own north and south pole. This demonstrates that magnetic {{d7}} cannot exist in isolation.

d6.tooltip: Each piece becomes its own complete magnet

d7.tooltip: Single isolated poles have never been observed

current_wires.title: Applying Current-Wire Field Concepts
current_wires.instructions: Apply your understanding of current-carrying wire fields to practical scenarios.

sentences.text: When current flows upward in a vertical wire, applying the right-hand grip rule shows the magnetic field circulates {{d1}} when viewed from above. Reversing the current direction would make the field circulate {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Thumb up, fingers curl which way?

sentences.text: Two parallel wires carrying current in the same direction will {{d3}} each other. If the currents flow in opposite directions, the wires will {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Same direction currents, same direction fields between

sentences.text: The strength of the magnetic field around a wire is {{d5}} to the current and {{d6}} with distance from the wire.

loops_solenoids.title: Applying Loop and Solenoid Concepts
loops_solenoids.instructions: Apply your understanding of electromagnet fields to practical scenarios.

sentences.text: Looking at a current loop from one side, if current flows clockwise, the magnetic field points {{d1}} from you through the loop. The field inside the loop is {{d2}} than outside.

d2.tooltip: Field lines are concentrated in the centre

sentences.text: A solenoid connected to a battery can be modelled as a bar magnet. The end where field lines emerge is the {{d3}} pole. Reversing the battery connections would reverse the {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Field lines exit from which pole?

sentences.text: Increasing the number of loops in a solenoid {{d5}} the magnetic field strength. Adding an iron core to a solenoid {{d6}} the field because iron is a {{d7}} material.

d5.tooltip: More loops means more concentrated field

d6.tooltip: Iron is strongly affected by magnetic fields

bar_magnets.title: Mastering Bar Magnet Field Concepts
bar_magnets.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by addressing common misconceptions and making comparisons.

sentences.text: Unlike electric charges which can exist as isolated positive or negative charges, magnets always have {{d1}} poles. If you could isolate a single magnetic pole, it would be called a {{d2}}, but these have {{d3}} been observed.

d1.tooltip: Magnets always come with two poles

sentences.text: Comparing field types: gravitational fields only {{d4}}, electric fields can attract or repel, and magnetic fields can also {{d5}}. This is because gravity only has one type of mass, while magnetism has {{d6}} types of poles.

d4.tooltip: Mass only comes in one type

d5.tooltip: Like poles repel, opposite poles attract

sentences.text: A common misconception is that magnetic field lines represent the path of moving charges. In reality, field lines show the {{d7}} a north pole would experience at each point. The field is a {{d8}} quantity because it has both magnitude and direction.

d7.tooltip: What would happen to a test pole?

current_wires.title: Mastering Current-Wire Field Concepts
current_wires.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by addressing common misconceptions and applications.

sentences.text: A common error is confusing the right-hand {{d1}} rule for wires with the right-hand {{d2}} rule for coils. For a straight wire, the thumb represents {{d3}}; for a coil, the thumb represents the field direction.

d2.tooltip: The rule for loops and solenoids

d3.tooltip: In the grip rule, what does the thumb show?

sentences.text: The magnetic field around a current-carrying wire is an example of a {{d4}} field because it {{d5}} over time while the current is constant. If the current varies, the field becomes a {{d6}} field.

d4.tooltip: Does the field change with time?

d5.tooltip: What happens when current is constant?

sentences.text: The discovery that electric currents produce magnetic fields, made by {{d7}} in 1820, established the connection between electricity and magnetism called {{d8}}.

d8.tooltip: The unified field theory of electricity and magnetism

loops_solenoids.title: Mastering Loop and Solenoid Concepts
loops_solenoids.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by addressing applications and comparisons.

sentences.text: The field inside a long solenoid is {{d1}} because the field lines are parallel and equally spaced. This is similar to the field between two {{d2}} charged parallel plates in electrostatics.

d1.tooltip: Parallel, equally-spaced field lines indicate what?

d2.tooltip: What creates a uniform electric field?

sentences.text: Electromagnets differ from permanent magnets because their field can be {{d3}} by changing the current. An electromagnet with no current has {{d4}} magnetic field, making them useful in applications like {{d5}}.

d3.tooltip: What can you do by varying current?

d4.tooltip: No current means no magnetic field

d5.tooltip: Where do you need to turn magnetism on and off?

sentences.text: The field outside a solenoid resembles that of a {{d6}} with field lines looping from one end to the other. Inside, the field points from the {{d7}} end to the {{d8}} end.

d6.tooltip: The external field pattern matches what?

d7.tooltip: Field lines go from S to N inside a magnet

magnetic_poles.name: Magnetic Poles
magnetic_poles.correct: All magnets have two poles called north and south. They are named after the geographic directions a compass points.

positive.error: Confusing magnetic poles with electric charges.
positive.fix: Electric charges are positive/negative. Magnetic poles are north/south.

negative.error: Confusing magnetic poles with electric charges.
negative.fix: Magnetic poles are north and south, not positive and negative.
negative.action: Electric and magnetic fields use different naming conventions.

strong.fix: North and south indicate where field lines exit and enter, not field strength.
strong.action: Think of poles as geographic directions, not intensity levels.

persistent.gap: You are confusing magnetic and electric terminology.
persistent.action: Make a comparison table: Electric (positive/negative charges) vs Magnetic (north/south poles).

magnetic_field_definition.name: Magnetic Field Definition
magnetic_field_definition.correct: A magnetic field is the region around a magnet where another magnet or magnetic material experiences a force.

electric field.error: Electric fields are produced by charges, not magnets.
electric field.fix: Magnets produce magnetic fields. Charges produce electric fields.
electric field.action: Associate magnets with magnetic fields, charges with electric fields.

gravitational field.error: Gravitational fields are produced by mass, not magnets.
gravitational field.fix: Different sources create different field types: mass → gravity, magnets → magnetism.
gravitational field.action: Match field type to source: magnets produce magnetic fields only.

magnetic force.error: Force and field are different concepts.
magnetic force.fix: A field is a region; a force is what an object experiences in that region.
magnetic force.action: Field = property of space. Force = effect on objects in that space.

persistent.gap: You are confusing different field types or fields with forces.
persistent.action: Review the three field types: gravitational (from mass), electric (from charge), magnetic (from magnets/currents).

field_line_direction.name: Field Line Direction
field_line_direction.correct: Magnetic field lines exit from the north pole and enter at the south pole outside the magnet.

south.fix: Field lines go FROM north TO south outside the magnet.
south.action: Mnemonic: North = eXit (X marks the spot where lines leave).

positive.error: Using electric field terminology for magnetic fields.
positive.fix: Magnetic fields use north/south, not positive/negative.
positive.action: Electric fields: away from positive. Magnetic fields: away from north.

negative.error: Using electric field terminology for magnetic fields.
negative.fix: Magnetic poles are north and south.
negative.action: Keep magnetic and electric conventions separate.

persistent.gap: You are not remembering the north-to-south convention for magnetic field lines.
persistent.action: Draw 5 bar magnets with field lines. Label N and S. Check lines go N → S outside.

field_line_density.name: Field Line Density
field_line_density.correct: Field lines closer together indicate a stronger magnetic field.

weaker.fix: More lines per area = stronger field. Fewer lines = weaker field.
weaker.action: Think of lines as representing field strength density.

uniform.error: Uniform means constant, but the question asks about strength.
uniform.fix: Line density shows field strength, not uniformity.
uniform.action: Close lines = strong field. Spread lines = weak field.

zero.error: Lines being close together does not mean zero field.
zero.fix: Close lines indicate strong field, not absence of field.
zero.action: Zero field means no lines at all.

persistent.gap: You do not understand what field line spacing represents.
persistent.action: Study field diagrams. More concentrated lines = stronger field. This applies to all field types.

pole_interactions.name: Pole Interactions
pole_interactions.correct: Like poles repel each other; opposite poles attract. Same rule as electric charges.

attract.fix: N-N and S-S repel. N-S attract.

repel.fix: N-S attract. Only like poles repel.

align.error: Alignment is what happens after attraction, not the interaction type.
align.fix: The interaction is attraction (for opposite) or repulsion (for like).
align.action: Focus on the force type: attract or repel.

neutralise.error: Poles cannot neutralise each other like charges can.
neutralise.fix: Magnetic poles always exist in pairs. They attract or repel, but don't cancel.
neutralise.action: Unlike electric charges, you cannot have a neutral magnetic pole.

persistent.gap: You are not applying the like-repels, opposite-attracts rule consistently.
persistent.action: Practice: N-N = repel, S-S = repel, N-S = attract. Test with real magnets if possible.

magnetic_dipoles.name: Magnetic Dipoles
magnetic_dipoles.correct: Magnets always exist as dipoles with both north and south poles. Monopoles have never been observed.

monopoles.error: Monopoles do not exist in nature.
monopoles.fix: Every magnet has both poles. Breaking a magnet creates smaller dipoles.
monopoles.action: Try to isolate one pole mentally—you cannot. Breaking creates two smaller magnets.

quadrupoles.error: Quadrupole is a different configuration (four poles arranged specifically).
quadrupoles.fix: Basic magnets are dipoles: exactly two poles, north and south.
quadrupoles.action: Dipole = two poles. The simplest magnetic configuration.

multipoles.error: Multipole is a general term; dipole is the specific answer.
multipoles.fix: Magnets are specifically dipoles—exactly two poles.
multipoles.action: Be specific: magnets are dipoles, not just 'multipoles.'

persistent.gap: You do not understand that magnets fundamentally have exactly two poles.
persistent.action: Research why monopoles have never been found. This is a fundamental property of magnetism.

wire_field_shape.name: Wire Field Shape
wire_field_shape.correct: A current-carrying wire produces circular magnetic field lines centred on the wire.

radial.error: Radial means pointing outward like spokes; the field is circular.
radial.fix: Field lines form closed circles around the wire.
radial.action: Visualise wrapping your hand around a wire—that's the field shape.

parallel.error: Parallel lines occur inside solenoids, not around single wires.
parallel.fix: Single wire = circular field. Solenoid = parallel field inside.
parallel.action: Draw a cross-section of a wire. Field lines are circles around it.

spiral.error: Field lines don't spiral; they form closed circular loops.
spiral.fix: Each field line is a complete circle at a fixed distance from the wire.
spiral.action: Field lines never spiral outward—they close on themselves.

persistent.gap: You are not visualising the circular field pattern around a wire.
persistent.action: Find images of iron filings around a current-carrying wire. Note the circular pattern.

grip_rule.name: Right-Hand Grip Rule
grip_rule.correct: Right-hand grip rule: thumb points in current direction, curled fingers show magnetic field direction.

left-hand grip.error: The rule uses the RIGHT hand, not left.
left-hand grip.fix: Always use your RIGHT hand for magnetic field direction around wires.
left-hand grip.action: Left hand is for motor effect (force). Right hand is for field direction.

right-hand slap.error: Slap rule is for force on conductors, not field direction.
right-hand slap.fix: Grip rule = field around wire. Slap rule = force on conductor in field.
right-hand slap.action: Different rules for different situations. Grip = finding field direction.

left-hand slap.error: Wrong hand and wrong rule type.
left-hand slap.fix: For field around a wire, use the right-hand GRIP rule.
left-hand slap.action: Memorise: field direction around wire = right-hand grip rule.

persistent.gap: You are confusing different hand rules and their applications.
persistent.action: Make a table: Grip rule (field direction) vs Slap rule (force direction). Both use right hand.

grip_rule_application.name: Grip Rule Application
grip_rule_application.correct: In the right-hand grip rule, thumb = conventional current direction, curled fingers = magnetic field direction.

fingers.error: The thumb points along the wire, not the fingers.
fingers.fix: Thumb along wire in current direction. Fingers curl around showing field.
fingers.action: Make the grip gesture. Your thumb goes along the wire.

palm.error: The palm is not used in the grip rule.
palm.fix: Grip rule uses thumb (current) and curled fingers (field).
palm.action: Close your hand in a grip. Thumb up = current up, fingers curl = field direction.

electron flow.error: Use conventional current, not electron flow.
electron flow.fix: Conventional current flows positive to negative (opposite to electrons).
electron flow.action: In physics, current direction is conventional: positive to negative terminal.

anticlockwise.error: This depends on the current direction and viewpoint.
anticlockwise.fix: Apply the rule: thumb in current direction, fingers curl to show field.
anticlockwise.action: Practice: current upward → field anticlockwise from above.

clockwise.error: This depends on the current direction and viewpoint.
clockwise.fix: Apply the rule: thumb in current direction, fingers curl to show field.
clockwise.action: Practice: current downward → field clockwise from above.

persistent.gap: You are not correctly applying the right-hand grip rule.
persistent.action: Practice with a pencil as a wire. Point thumb along 'current' direction. See which way fingers curl.

vector_notation.name: Vector Into/Out of Page
vector_notation.correct: Cross (×) represents a vector into the page (arrow tail). Dot (•) represents a vector out of the page (arrow tip).

dot.error: Reversed. Dot is out, cross is in.
dot.fix: Think of an arrow: coming toward you, you see the point (dot). Going away, you see the feathers (cross).
dot.action: Arrow toward you = dot. Arrow away from you = cross.

cross.error: Reversed. Cross is in, dot is out.
cross.fix: Cross = tail of arrow = going away = into page.
cross.action: Visualise arrows: tip coming at you = dot, tail going away = cross.

circle.error: Circles are not the standard notation.
circle.fix: Use × for into page, • for out of page.

arrow.fix: When a vector goes into or out of the page, use × or • notation.
arrow.action: Practice drawing 3D vectors on paper using × and • symbols.

persistent.gap: You are not remembering the arrow analogy for × and • notation.
persistent.action: Draw an arrow coming toward you (you see the tip = •). Draw one going away (you see the feathers = ×).

loop_field_concentration.name: Loop Field Concentration
loop_field_concentration.correct: The magnetic field is concentrated and strongest in the centre of a current-carrying loop.

edge.error: Field lines spread out at the edges, making the field weaker there.
edge.fix: Field lines bunch together in the centre, making it strongest there.
edge.action: Look at a loop field diagram. Lines are closest together in the middle.

outside.error: The field outside is weaker and more spread out.
outside.fix: Field is concentrated inside the loop, spread out outside.
outside.action: A loop focuses the field inward, like a lens focuses light.

surface.error: The surface of the wire is not where the field is strongest.
surface.fix: The field passes through the centre of the loop where it's strongest.
surface.action: Think of the loop as concentrating field lines through its centre.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how a loop concentrates the magnetic field.
persistent.action: Study field line diagrams for current loops. Notice how lines bunch up in the centre.

coil_rule.name: Right-Hand Coil Rule
coil_rule.formula: Fingers = I around, Thumb = B through
coil_rule.correct: Right-hand coil rule: curl fingers in current direction around loop, thumb points in magnetic field direction through loop.

left-hand coil.error: Always use the RIGHT hand for magnetic field rules.
left-hand coil.fix: Right-hand coil rule: fingers curl with current, thumb shows field.
left-hand coil.action: For all field direction rules, use your right hand.

right-hand grip.error: Grip rule is for straight wires, coil rule is for loops.
right-hand grip.fix: For loops/solenoids, use the coil rule. For straight wires, use grip rule.
right-hand grip.action: Coil rule: curl fingers = current direction, thumb = field direction.

left-hand grip.error: Wrong hand and wrong rule type.
left-hand grip.fix: For loops, use right-hand COIL rule.
left-hand grip.action: Match the rule to the situation: loops use coil rule.

persistent.gap: You are confusing grip rule (wires) with coil rule (loops/solenoids).
persistent.action: Make flashcards: Grip rule = straight wire (thumb = I). Coil rule = loop (thumb = B).

coil_rule_application.name: Coil Rule Application
coil_rule_application.formula: Curl with current, thumb shows field
coil_rule_application.correct: In the coil rule, curled fingers follow current around the loop, thumb points in field direction through the loop.

magnetic field.error: In the coil rule, fingers follow current, not field.
magnetic field.fix: Fingers = current direction around loop. Thumb = field direction through loop.
magnetic field.action: Coil rule swaps the roles from grip rule. Memorise the difference.

electron flow.fix: Conventional current flows from positive to negative terminal.
electron flow.action: Always use conventional current for these rules.

force.error: The coil rule finds field direction, not force.
force.fix: Coil rule gives magnetic field direction through the loop.
force.action: This rule is for finding B, not F.

current.error: In the coil rule, the thumb shows field, not current.
current.fix: Thumb = field direction (B). Fingers = current direction (I).
current.action: Coil rule: thumb = B through loop. Different from grip rule.

north pole.error: The thumb shows field direction, which points toward the north pole end.
north pole.fix: Thumb shows where field exits (north end) but we call it field direction.
north pole.action: Field direction through loop = direction thumb points = north pole end.

persistent.gap: You are confusing what the thumb and fingers represent in the coil rule.
persistent.action: Practice: Grip rule thumb = current. Coil rule thumb = field. Opposite roles.

solenoid_as_magnet.name: Solenoid as Bar Magnet
solenoid_as_magnet.correct: A solenoid produces a field pattern identical to a bar magnet, with distinct north and south ends.

electric dipole.error: Electric dipoles involve charges, not magnetic effects.
electric dipole.fix: A solenoid is an electromagnet, so it resembles a bar magnet.
electric dipole.action: Solenoid with current = magnetic dipole, not electric dipole.

point charge.error: Point charges produce radial electric fields, not magnetic fields.
point charge.fix: Solenoids produce dipole magnetic fields like bar magnets.
point charge.action: Solenoid field lines loop from north to south, like a bar magnet.

gravitational mass.error: Mass produces gravitational fields, not magnetic fields.
gravitational mass.fix: Solenoids are electromagnets with bar-magnet-like field patterns.
gravitational mass.action: Compare a solenoid field diagram to a bar magnet—they match.

persistent.gap: You are not recognising that solenoids create bar-magnet-like fields.
persistent.action: Look at field diagrams for both solenoids and bar magnets. They are essentially identical.

solenoid_field_strength.name: Solenoid Field Strength
solenoid_field_strength.correct: The magnetic field inside a solenoid is strong because the fields from all the loops add together.

weak.error: The field inside is strong, not weak.
weak.fix: Multiple loops concentrate field lines inside the solenoid.
weak.action: More loops = more field contribution = stronger total field inside.

zero.error: The field inside a solenoid is strong, not zero.
zero.fix: Fields from each loop add up inside the solenoid.
zero.action: The field is strongest inside, weakest outside.

variable.error: The field inside a long solenoid is uniform, not variable.
variable.fix: Inside a solenoid, the field is constant in both strength and direction.
variable.action: Variable field occurs outside the solenoid, not inside.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how solenoids concentrate magnetic field.
persistent.action: Study how individual loop fields add together inside a solenoid to create a strong uniform field.

solenoid_field_uniformity.name: Solenoid Field Uniformity
solenoid_field_uniformity.correct: The field inside a long solenoid is uniform—parallel field lines with constant strength.

non-uniform.error: Inside a solenoid, the field is uniform (constant).
non-uniform.fix: The field only becomes non-uniform near the ends of the solenoid.
non-uniform.action: In the central region, field lines are parallel and evenly spaced = uniform.

radial.error: Radial fields spread outward; solenoid fields are parallel inside.
radial.fix: Field lines inside a solenoid are straight and parallel to the axis.
radial.action: Radial = point charge. Parallel = solenoid interior.

random.error: The field inside has a definite direction and uniformity.
random.fix: Inside a solenoid, the field points along the axis uniformly.
random.action: Field lines inside are organised, not random.

persistent.gap: You do not understand the uniform nature of solenoid interior fields.
persistent.action: Compare solenoid interior (uniform, parallel) to exterior (non-uniform, curved).

earth_magnetic_field.name: Earth's Magnetic Field
earth_magnetic_field.correct: Earth's geographic north pole is near a magnetic south pole, which is why compass north poles point there.

south.error: Compasses point to geographic north, not south.
south.fix: The compass north pole is attracted to Earth's magnetic south pole, located near geographic north.
south.action: Remember: compass points geographic north because opposites attract.

north.error: Earth's magnetic north pole is near geographic south.
north.fix: Geographic north has Earth's magnetic SOUTH pole (opposites attract).
north.action: A compass north pole is attracted to Earth's magnetic south pole = geographic north.

positive.error: Earth's poles are magnetic (north/south), not electric (positive/negative).
positive.fix: Magnetic poles are north and south, not positive and negative.
positive.action: Don't confuse magnetic and electric terminology.

negative.error: Earth's poles are magnetic, not electric.
negative.fix: Use north/south for magnetic poles, not positive/negative.

persistent.gap: You are confusing Earth's geographic and magnetic poles.
persistent.action: Draw a diagram: Geographic North has Magnetic South. Compass north points there because opposites attract.

two_magnet_fields.name: Two Magnet Field Patterns
two_magnet_fields.correct: Between opposite poles (N-S), the field is approximately uniform with parallel field lines.

non-uniform.error: Between opposite poles, the field is approximately uniform.
non-uniform.fix: Field lines run straight from N to S between opposite poles.
non-uniform.action: Non-uniform fields occur between like poles, not opposite poles.

zero.error: The field between opposite poles is strong, not zero.
zero.fix: Field lines connect the two poles, creating a strong field between them.
zero.action: Zero field points occur between like poles, not opposite poles.

radial.error: Radial describes fields around point sources, not between poles.
radial.fix: Between opposite poles, field lines are parallel, not radial.
radial.action: The field between opposite poles looks like the uniform field inside a solenoid.

persistent.gap: You do not understand field patterns between different pole configurations.
persistent.action: Draw both scenarios: opposite poles (parallel lines) and like poles (diverging lines).

like_pole_fields.name: Like Pole Field Patterns
like_pole_fields.correct: Between like poles (N-N or S-S), field lines diverge because the poles repel.

converge.error: Lines diverge (spread apart) between like poles, not converge.
converge.fix: Repulsion causes field lines to spread away from each other.
converge.action: Like poles repel → field lines push apart → diverge.

remain parallel.error: Parallel lines occur between opposite poles, not like poles.
remain parallel.fix: Like poles create a diverging field pattern with a neutral point between.
remain parallel.action: Opposite poles = parallel. Like poles = diverging.

disappear.error: Field lines don't disappear; they change direction.
disappear.fix: Between like poles, field lines curve away from the gap.
disappear.action: There's a neutral point between like poles where field is zero, but lines exist elsewhere.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how repulsion affects field line patterns.
persistent.action: Visualise: two north poles push field lines away from the gap between them.

parallel_wire_forces.name: Parallel Wire Forces
parallel_wire_forces.formula: Same I = attract, Opposite I = repel
parallel_wire_forces.correct: Parallel wires with current in the same direction attract; opposite directions repel.

attract.fix: Same direction = attract. Opposite direction = repel.
attract.action: Think: same → attract, opposite → repel (for currents).

repel.error: Same direction currents attract, not repel.
repel.fix: Wires with current in the same direction attract each other.
repel.action: This is counterintuitive but physically correct. Same currents attract.

not interact with.error: Parallel current-carrying wires always interact magnetically.
not interact with.fix: The magnetic fields of the wires interact, creating forces.
not interact with.action: Any current-carrying wires near each other will exert forces on each other.

neutralise.error: The wires don't neutralise; they attract or repel.
neutralise.fix: The magnetic forces cause physical attraction or repulsion.
neutralise.action: Wires will move toward or away from each other, not neutralise.

persistent.gap: You are not remembering the parallel wire force rule.
persistent.action: Memorise: Same direction currents ATTRACT (seems backwards but it's true). Opposite directions REPEL.

wire_field_strength.name: Wire Field Strength Factors
wire_field_strength.correct: Magnetic field strength around a wire is proportional to current and inversely proportional to distance.

inversely proportional.error: Field strength is directly proportional to current, not inversely.
inversely proportional.fix: More current = stronger field. Field ∝ I (direct relationship).
inversely proportional.action: Double the current, double the field strength.

unrelated.error: Field strength depends directly on current.
unrelated.fix: Greater current produces a stronger magnetic field.
unrelated.action: The formula shows B ∝ I. They are definitely related.

increases.error: Field strength decreases with distance, not increases.
increases.fix: Further from the wire = weaker field.
increases.action: Field spreads out with distance, becoming weaker.

stays constant.error: Field strength varies with distance from the wire.
stays constant.fix: The field is strongest close to the wire and weakens with distance.
stays constant.action: Move away from a wire = weaker field. Not constant.

oscillates.error: For DC current, the field doesn't oscillate.
oscillates.fix: With steady current, the field decreases smoothly with distance.
oscillates.action: Oscillating fields occur with AC, not DC current.

persistent.gap: You are not understanding how current and distance affect field strength around a wire.
persistent.action: Remember: B ∝ I (more current = stronger). B ∝ 1/r (more distance = weaker).

static_vs_changing.name: Static vs Changing Fields
static_vs_changing.correct: A static field does not change over time. A changing field varies with time.

changing.error: A constant current produces a static (unchanging) field.
changing.fix: Static means not changing with time. Constant current = static field.
changing.action: If current is steady, field is static. If current varies, field changes.

uniform.error: Uniform describes spatial variation, static describes time variation.
uniform.fix: Static = doesn't change with time. Uniform = same everywhere in space.

static.error: If current varies, the field must change too.
static.fix: Varying current → changing field. Constant current → static field.
static.action: Field follows current: changing current = changing field.

does not change.error: If current varies, the field must change too.
does not change.fix: The field is directly linked to the current producing it.
does not change.action: Current varies → field varies. They change together.

increases.error: With constant current, the field doesn't change at all.
increases.fix: Constant current means the field stays the same over time.
increases.action: No change in current = no change in field.

decreases.error: With constant current, the field remains steady.
decreases.fix: Static field means constant—neither increasing nor decreasing.
decreases.action: Steady current produces a steady (static) field.

oscillates.error: DC (constant) current produces a static field.
oscillates.fix: Only AC (alternating) current produces an oscillating field.
oscillates.action: Static field = DC current. Oscillating field = AC current.

persistent.gap: You are confusing static/changing (time) with uniform/non-uniform (space).
persistent.action: Make a table: Static vs Changing (about TIME). Uniform vs Non-uniform (about SPACE).

historical_context.name: Historical Discovery
historical_context.correct: Hans Christian Ørsted discovered in 1820 that electric currents produce magnetic fields.

Faraday.error: Faraday discovered electromagnetic induction, not current-producing fields.
Faraday.fix: Ørsted discovered current → field. Faraday discovered changing field → current.
Faraday.action: Ørsted 1820: current produces field. Faraday 1831: changing field produces current.

Ampère.error: Ampère quantified the relationship after Ørsted's discovery.
Ampère.fix: Ørsted made the initial discovery; Ampère developed the mathematics.

Maxwell.fix: Ørsted's 1820 discovery came before Maxwell's unified theory.

persistent.gap: You are confusing the contributions of different electromagnetic pioneers.
persistent.action: Learn the timeline: Ørsted (1820) = current→field. Faraday (1831) = field→current. Maxwell (1860s) = unified theory.

electromagnetism_term.name: Electromagnetism
electromagnetism_term.correct: Electromagnetism is the unified theory connecting electric and magnetic phenomena.

electromagnetic induction.error: Induction is one part of electromagnetism, not the whole field.
electromagnetic induction.fix: Electromagnetism is the broad field. Induction is a specific phenomenon within it.
electromagnetic induction.action: Electromagnetism = general connection. Induction = specific process (changing field → current).

magnetostatics.error: Magnetostatics is only about static (unchanging) magnetic fields.
magnetostatics.fix: Electromagnetism covers both static and changing fields.
magnetostatics.action: Magnetostatics is a subset of electromagnetism dealing with constant fields only.

electrochemistry.error: Electrochemistry involves chemical reactions, not magnetic fields.
electrochemistry.fix: Electromagnetism is about fields. Electrochemistry is about reactions.
electrochemistry.action: Different field entirely: electrochemistry = chemistry with electricity.

persistent.gap: You are confusing related but different physics terms.
persistent.action: Define each: Electromagnetism (field), Induction (changing field→current), Magnetostatics (static fields only).

rule_distinction.name: Grip vs Coil Rule
rule_distinction.correct: Grip rule is for straight wires (thumb = current). Coil rule is for loops/solenoids (thumb = field).

coil.error: The grip rule is for straight wires, not coils.
coil.fix: Straight wire = grip rule. Loops and solenoids = coil rule.
coil.action: Match the geometry: straight = grip, curved = coil.

grip.error: Loops and solenoids use the coil rule, not grip rule.
grip.fix: For loops, use coil rule: fingers = current, thumb = field.
grip.action: Coil rule specifically for coiled geometries.

slap.error: Slap rule is for force on conductors, not field direction.
slap.fix: Grip and coil rules find field direction. Slap rule finds force direction.
slap.action: Three rules: Grip (wire field), Coil (loop field), Slap (force).

palm.error: Palm rule is another name for slap rule—for forces, not fields.
palm.fix: Field direction uses grip (wire) or coil (loop) rules.

field direction.error: In the grip rule, the thumb shows current, not field.
field direction.fix: Grip rule: thumb = current, fingers = field. Coil rule: opposite assignment.
field direction.action: The rules swap thumb meaning: grip (thumb = I), coil (thumb = B).

persistent.gap: You are mixing up the different hand rules and what they determine.
persistent.action: Create a summary table: Grip (straight wire, thumb=I), Coil (loop/solenoid, thumb=B), Slap (force, different hand position).

uniform_fields.name: Uniform Field Regions
uniform_fields.correct: A uniform field has parallel, equally-spaced field lines indicating constant magnitude and direction.

non-uniform.error: Parallel, equally-spaced lines indicate uniform field.
non-uniform.fix: Non-uniform fields have curved or variably-spaced lines.
non-uniform.action: Uniform = parallel and even. Non-uniform = curved or uneven.

zero.error: Parallel lines indicate a uniform field exists, not zero field.
zero.fix: Zero field would have no lines at all.
zero.action: Lines present = field present. Parallel lines = uniform field.

radial.error: Radial means pointing outward from a centre; uniform means parallel.
radial.fix: Radial fields spread out; uniform fields stay parallel.
radial.action: Radial = point source. Uniform = parallel plates or solenoid interior.

persistent.gap: You are not recognising visual indicators of uniform fields.
persistent.action: Study: uniform field = parallel lines, constant spacing. Found inside solenoids and between parallel plates.

field_comparison.name: Comparing Field Types
field_comparison.formula: Gravity: attract only. E&M: attract and repel
field_comparison.correct: Gravity only attracts (one mass type). Electric and magnetic fields can attract or repel (two pole/charge types).

repel.error: Gravity only attracts; it cannot repel.
repel.fix: Mass only comes in one type, so gravity is always attractive.
repel.action: Gravity: one mass type → always attract. No antigravity.

attract or repel.error: Gravity can only attract, not repel.
attract or repel.fix: Electric and magnetic forces can attract or repel; gravity cannot.
attract or repel.action: Two charge types or pole types allow repulsion. One mass type means only attraction.

only attract.fix: Like poles repel, opposite poles attract.
only attract.action: Magnetism has two pole types, so both attraction and repulsion are possible.

only repel.error: Magnetic fields can also attract (opposite poles).
only repel.fix: N-S attract, N-N and S-S repel.
only repel.action: Both attraction and repulsion occur in magnetism.

one.error: Magnetism has two types of poles, not one.
one.fix: North and south are two distinct pole types.
one.action: Mass: one type. Charge: two types. Poles: two types.

three.error: There are exactly two magnetic pole types.
three.fix: Only north and south poles exist.
three.action: Two poles: north and south. No third type.

persistent.gap: You are not understanding why gravity differs from electromagnetic forces.
persistent.action: Key insight: gravity has one mass type (attract only). Electric and magnetic have two types each (attract and repel possible).

magnetic_monopoles.name: Magnetic Monopoles
magnetic_monopoles.correct: Magnetic monopoles (isolated single poles) have never been observed despite extensive searching.

always.fix: Every magnet has both north and south poles.
always.action: No isolated magnetic pole has ever been detected.

sometimes.error: Monopoles have never been observed at all.
sometimes.fix: Despite theoretical predictions, no monopole has been found.
sometimes.action: Zero confirmed observations of magnetic monopoles.

rarely.error: Monopoles have never been observed, not even rarely.
rarely.fix: The search continues, but no monopole has been found.
rarely.action: Never means zero observations, not rare observations.

persistent.gap: You are not clear on the status of magnetic monopoles.
persistent.action: Research: Despite being theoretically possible, no magnetic monopole has ever been observed. This is a fundamental mystery.

field_line_meaning.name: Field Line Interpretation
field_line_meaning.formula: Direction of force on test pole
field_line_meaning.correct: Field lines show the direction of force a north pole would experience at each point in space.

path of electrons.error: Field lines are not particle paths.
path of electrons.fix: Lines show force direction, not how particles move.
path of electrons.action: A test north pole would feel a force along the field line.

flow of energy.error: Field lines don't represent energy flow.
flow of energy.fix: They show force direction on a test north pole.
flow of energy.action: Think: where would a compass needle point? That's the field direction.

speed of charges.error: Field lines indicate direction, not speed.
speed of charges.fix: Lines show which way a north pole would be pushed.
speed of charges.action: Field magnitude (speed of force) is shown by line density, not line direction.

persistent.gap: You are misinterpreting what field lines represent.
persistent.action: Remember: field lines show the direction of force on a test north pole. Nothing more, nothing less.

field_as_vector.name: Field as Vector Quantity
field_as_vector.correct: Magnetic field (B) is a vector quantity with both magnitude (strength in tesla) and direction.

scalar.fix: Magnetic field has magnitude AND direction, making it a vector.
scalar.action: Scalars have only magnitude (like mass). Fields have direction too.

tensor.error: The magnetic field itself is a vector, not a tensor.
tensor.fix: B is represented by a vector at each point in space.
tensor.action: Vector = magnitude + direction. That describes magnetic field.

constant.error: Constant refers to variation, not the type of quantity.
constant.fix: The field is a vector; whether it's constant depends on the source.
constant.action: Vector describes the mathematical nature, not whether it changes.

persistent.gap: You are not clear on why magnetic field is a vector.
persistent.action: Review: vectors have magnitude and direction. At every point, B has a strength (tesla) and points somewhere.

solenoid_polarity.name: Solenoid Polarity
solenoid_polarity.correct: Reversing the current in a solenoid reverses its magnetic polarity (swaps north and south ends).

field strength.error: Reversing current reverses polarity, not necessarily strength.
field strength.fix: The same current magnitude but opposite direction swaps N and S.
field strength.action: Direction reverses, magnitude stays the same.

field shape.error: The shape stays the same; only the direction reverses.
field shape.fix: Reversing current swaps which end is north and which is south.
field shape.action: Shape is unchanged. Polarity (which end is which) reverses.

number of field lines.error: The number of lines depends on current magnitude, not direction.
number of field lines.fix: Reversing direction swaps poles but keeps field strength.
number of field lines.action: Same current magnitude = same field strength = same number of lines.

persistent.gap: You are confusing polarity with other field properties.
persistent.action: Polarity = which end is north/south. Reversing current flips this. Strength and shape stay the same.

solenoid_field_factors.name: Factors Affecting Solenoid Field
solenoid_field_factors.correct: Solenoid field strength increases with more loops (n) and greater current (I).

decreases.error: More loops means stronger field, not weaker.
decreases.fix: Each loop adds to the total field inside the solenoid.
decreases.action: More loops = more field contribution = stronger total field.

does not change.error: Number of loops directly affects field strength.
does not change.fix: More loops concentrate more field lines inside.
does not change.action: Double the loops, double the field strength.

randomises.error: More loops organise the field, they don't randomise it.
randomises.fix: Additional loops reinforce and strengthen the uniform field inside.
randomises.action: Loops add constructively to create a stronger, more uniform field.

persistent.gap: You are not understanding how solenoid design affects field strength.
persistent.action: Key factors: more loops = stronger, more current = stronger, iron core = much stronger.

iron_core_effect.name: Iron Core Effect
iron_core_effect.correct: Adding an iron core greatly increases solenoid field strength because iron is ferromagnetic.

decreases.error: Iron cores increase, not decrease, field strength.
decreases.fix: Iron becomes magnetised and adds its own field to the solenoid's.

does not change.error: Iron cores dramatically increase field strength.
does not change.fix: Iron becomes temporarily magnetised, multiplying the field.
does not change.action: This is why electromagnets used in industry have iron cores.

slightly increases.error: Iron cores GREATLY increase the field, not slightly.
slightly increases.fix: Ferromagnetic materials can multiply field strength by factors of hundreds.
slightly increases.action: Iron's effect is dramatic—that's why it's used in motors and generators.

persistent.gap: You underestimate the effect of ferromagnetic cores on electromagnets.
persistent.action: Research: iron cores can increase field strength by 100-1000 times. This is why all practical electromagnets use iron cores.

ferromagnetic_materials.name: Ferromagnetic Materials
ferromagnetic_materials.correct: Ferromagnetic materials (iron, nickel, cobalt) become strongly magnetised in magnetic fields.

diamagnetic.error: Diamagnetic materials weakly REPEL magnetic fields.
diamagnetic.fix: Ferromagnetic materials are strongly ATTRACTED to magnets.
diamagnetic.action: Diamagnetic = weak repulsion. Ferromagnetic = strong attraction.

paramagnetic.error: Paramagnetic materials are weakly attracted; ferromagnetic are strongly attracted.
paramagnetic.fix: Ferromagnetic response is much stronger than paramagnetic.
paramagnetic.action: Para = weak attraction. Ferro = strong attraction.

non-magnetic.fix: Iron is the archetypal ferromagnetic material.
non-magnetic.action: Ferromagnetic materials like iron are strongly affected by magnets.

persistent.gap: You are confusing different types of magnetic material responses.
persistent.action: Learn the hierarchy: Ferromagnetic (strong attraction) > Paramagnetic (weak attraction) > Diamagnetic (weak repulsion).

electromagnet_control.name: Electromagnet Control
electromagnet_control.correct: Electromagnets can be switched on/off and their strength controlled by varying the current.

eliminated permanently.error: The field can be restored by restoring current.
eliminated permanently.fix: Electromagnets are controllable—field returns when current flows again.
eliminated permanently.action: This is a key advantage: on/off control, unlike permanent magnets.

increased only.error: Current can be increased OR decreased to control field.
increased only.fix: You can make the field stronger, weaker, or zero by controlling current.
increased only.action: Full control: increase, decrease, or turn off the field.

decreased only.error: Current can be adjusted in either direction.
decreased only.fix: Electromagnets offer complete field control through current.
decreased only.action: Any field strength from zero to maximum is achievable.

persistent.gap: You are not appreciating the controllability advantage of electromagnets.
persistent.action: Compare: permanent magnets = always on. Electromagnets = adjustable and switchable.

electromagnet_applications.name: Electromagnet Applications
electromagnet_applications.correct: Electromagnets are used where magnetism needs to be switched on and off (cranes, motors, relays).

refrigerator magnets.error: Refrigerator magnets are permanent magnets, not electromagnets.
refrigerator magnets.fix: Fridge magnets don't need to be switched—they use permanent magnets.
refrigerator magnets.action: Electromagnets are used where switching is needed.

compass needles.fix: Compasses need to stay magnetised always—permanent magnets work.
compass needles.action: Electromagnets would need constant power; compasses use permanent magnets.

bar magnets.error: Bar magnets are permanent magnets by definition.
bar magnets.fix: Electromagnets are different from permanent bar magnets.
bar magnets.action: Bar magnet = permanent. Solenoid with current = electromagnet.

persistent.gap: You are not distinguishing electromagnet applications from permanent magnet applications.
persistent.action: Rule: need to switch on/off? → electromagnet. Always need magnetism? → permanent magnet.

solenoid_internal_field.name: Solenoid Internal Field Direction
solenoid_internal_field.correct: Inside a solenoid (or bar magnet), the field points from the south pole end to the north pole end.

north.error: Inside the magnet, field goes FROM south TO north.
north.fix: Field lines are continuous loops. Inside: S to N. Outside: N to S.
north.action: Remember: field lines form closed loops. Inside is opposite to outside.

south.error: The field points TO north inside, meaning it comes FROM south.
south.fix: Inside: S → N. This completes the loop started outside (N → S).
south.action: Draw the complete field line loop to see the internal direction.

positive.error: Using electric terminology for magnetic fields.
positive.fix: Magnetic poles are north and south, not positive and negative.
positive.action: Keep electric and magnetic conventions separate.

negative.error: Using electric terminology for magnetic fields.
negative.fix: Use north and south for magnetic poles.

persistent.gap: You are not visualising the complete field line loops in magnets.
persistent.action: Draw a complete field line: exits at north → loops outside → enters at south → runs through inside S→N → exits at north again.
